question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate, professional responses. Be sure to ensure that the generated code is executable for demonstration. Please write code to implement a video editing tool where users can upload multiple video clips, crop each clip, and adjust the order through drag and drop. The tool needs to support adding transition effects (fade-in/fade-out, cross-dissolve, wipe, etc. - at least 5 different effects), allow users to add text annotations and simple animation effects to videos. After completing the edits, users can preview the composite result and export it as MP4 format.

checklist.title: Is the video upload and management system fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code properly implements file upload functionality for multiple video clips, includes proper MIME type validation, provides progress indicators during upload, and organizes uploaded clips in a manageable interface. Score 0 if upload functionality is missing, 5 if basic upload works without validation or progress indicators, and 10 if the system handles all aspects professionally including error handling for invalid file formats or failed uploads.

checklist.title: Are the basic video cropping/trimming functions properly implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes accurate video trimming capabilities with frame-precise control. The implementation should provide visual indicators for start/end points, preview thumbnails at different timestamps, and maintain video quality during trimming operations. Deduct 5 points if the trimming lacks frame-level precision, 3 points if there's no visual timeline for selection, and 3 points if the preview mechanism is absent. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the drag-and-drop reordering functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code implements an intuitive drag-and-drop interface for reordering video clips, with visual feedback during dragging (such as placeholder indicators), smooth animations when clips are reordered, and proper state management to maintain the new sequence. Deduct 5 points if drag operations are jerky or imprecise, 3 points if visual feedback is missing during drag operations, and 5 points if the reordering doesn't persist correctly. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are the required transition effects implemented with proper controls?
checklist.description: Verify that the code includes at least 5 distinct transition effects (fade-in/fade-out, cross-dissolve, wipe, etc.) with appropriate preview capabilities and duration controls. Each transition should be properly rendered between clips in the preview. Deduct 2 points for each missing required transition type, 5 points if transitions cannot be previewed, and 3 points if duration controls are missing or imprecise. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as browser compatibility issues, interrupted uploads, corrupted video files, memory constraints with large videos, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-assisted editing suggestions 2. Automatic beat detection for music-synchronized transitions 3. One-click theme application across multiple clips and transitions). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple video players coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to video editing (e.g., a built-in game) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive background animations). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating video processing logic/UI components/file handling), unit test coverage, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size â‰¥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the video preview and export functionality complete and reliable?
checklist.description: Judge whether the preview and export functions meet professional standards: 1) Real-time preview reflects all edits accurately 2) Export process shows clear progress indication 3) Multiple quality/format options for export 4) Exported files maintain original resolution quality. Deduct 5 points if preview performance is laggy, 5 points if export fails on complex projects, 3 points if exported files show quality degradation, and 3 points if format options are limited. The full score is 10 points.
